header.title: The Magical Calendar: A Synthesis of Magical Symbolism from the Seventeenth-Century Renaissance of Medieval Occultism

central_thesis: The Magical Calendar presents a comprehensive synthesis of magical and numerical symbolic philosophy, drawing from Renaissance and medieval Hermetic, Kabbalistic, and grimoire traditions. It serves as an operative guide for understanding the interconnectedness of the cosmos, from divine names to terrestrial elements, and for aligning human will with celestial influences through symbolic and 'white' magical practices, emphasizing a holistic, non-analytical mode of thought essential for Hermetic spiritual development.

structure_content.summary: This section details the historical context of the original 1620 Magical Calendar engraving, identifying Johann Baptista Grosschedel von Aicha as the compiler, Johannes Theodorus de Bry as the publisher/engraver, and Mathieu Merian as the engraver. It discusses the work's sources (Agrippa, Peter of Abano, pseudo-Paracelsus), its omission of 'demonic' elements to present 'purest, spiritual, white magic,' and its lineage through manuscript and later printed editions. The introduction also frames the Calendar as a vehicle for synthesizing magical and numerical symbolic philosophy, advocating for a holistic 'Hermetic mode of thought' for spiritual evolution.

This chapter introduces the Monad, represented by the one-lettered Name of God, Yod. It explores the concept of primal unity, the beginning and end of all things, without origin or conclusion. Key correspondences include the One Soul of the World, One World, One Philosopher's Stone, One Heart, and One Supreme Intelligence, emphasizing unity, piety, harmony, and the origin of all numbers.

Focusing on the Binary (Iah, El), this section describes it as the number of marriage and the Microcosm, denoting material procreation. It lists dualistic correspondences such as Divine/Human Natures, Angelic/Soul Substances, Sun/Moon Luminaries, Earth/Water Elements, Heart/Brain Principles, and Dragon's Head/Tail. It also outlines planetary associations for the hours of day and night, vital for timing magical operations, and provides a table of hour names from Peter of Abano’s Heptameron.

This chapter delves into the Ternary (Shaddai) as the sacred, powerful, and perfect number. It presents extensive correspondences organized into sets of three, including Divine Persons (Father, Son, Holy Spirit), Angelic Hierarchies (Supreme, Middle, Lower), Species of Soul (Intellectual, Sentient, Vegetable), theological virtues (Hope, Faith, Charity), world principles, intellectual powers, kingdoms of creation, elements (Pure, Compounded, Decomposed), and alchemical principles (Sulphur, Salt, Mercury). Various symbolic figures, including hexagrams and pentagrams, are illustrated, alongside a table indicating zodiacal signs per day.

Exploring the Quaternary (Tetragrammaton) as the root and foundation of numbers and nature, this section provides comprehensive correspondences in fours. These include the four elements (Fire, Air, Water, Earth), their governors and angels (Raphael, Michael, Gabriel, Uriel), winds, points of the compass, zodiacal triplicities, elemental qualities (Luminosity, Transparency, Mobility, Solidity), elements of man, powers of the soul, stages of existence, points of heaven, movements in nature, fundamentals of nature, mathematics, life force, metaphysical aspects, and moral virtues. Detailed tables for humors, seasons, evangelists, and sacred animals are also included.

The Quinary (Ihesuh) is presented as the half of the Denary, sacred to Mercury, representing the balance of even and odd. It enumerates correspondences such as the five wounds of Jesus, corrupt species, vain powers (Vigor, Sensation, Coveting, Anger, Calculating), human senses (Sight, Hearing, Smell, Taste, Touch), wandering stars (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, Mercury), mixed species, and animal species. Illustrations connect chiromancy of the hands and human figures to planetary and zodiacal signs.

This chapter defines the Senary (El Gibor) as the number of perfection, redemption, and Man. It outlines correspondences including orders of angels (Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones), planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars), global circles (Arctic, Antarctic, Tropic), characteristics of matter, qualities of substance, grades in man (Intellect, Memory, Perception), wandering planets (Moon, Mars, Mercury), and various positional aspects, with allusions to redemption and divine creation.

Dedicated extensively to the Septenary (Ararita) as the vehicle of human life, replete with power and sacred to the Holy Spirit, this chapter provides a detailed breakdown for each of the seven planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon). For each planet, it lists gifts of the Holy Spirit, associated angels and spirits, houses of exaltation and decline, sigils, characters, divine letters, and specific onomantic tables (e.g., Albumasar for Saturn, Pythagoras for Jupiter, Ptolemy for Mars). It also includes the planetary magic squares and tables of fortunate/unfortunate days, essential for operative magic.

The Octonary (Tetragrammaton Vedaath) is depicted as the number of Eternity and the preservation of health. Correspondences are detailed in eights, including gifts of the Beatitudes (Inheritance, Wholeness, Power, Victory), types of Beatitudes (Peacemakers, Hungry, Meek, Persecuted), visible heavens (Fixed Stars, Saturn, Jupiter, Mercury), ornaments of priests, divisions of qualities (Dryness of Earth, Coldness of Water, Wetness of Air, Warmth of Fire), and the Most Sacred Tablets of the Fathers, illustrated with unique seal-like symbols attributed to figures like Adam, Moses, and Solomon.

This section explores the Nonary (Tetragrammaton Sabaoth) as representing the celestial spheres and divine spirits, sacred to the Muses. It organizes correspondences into nines, encompassing angelic choirs (Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones, Dominations, Potestates, Virtues, Principalities, Archangels, Angels), ruling angels for the heavens, symbolic stones (Sapphire, Emerald, Ruby, Beryl, Onyx, Crystal, Jasper, Topaz, Sardonyx), moving spheres, the Muses (Calliope, Urania, Polyhymnia, Terpsichore, Clio, Melpomene, Erato, Euterpe, Thalia), interior and exterior senses, and obscure Bacchic Muses.

The Denary (Elohim Sabaoth) is described as the end and fulfillment of the Numbers, a perfect number embodying many powers. Its correspondences are presented in tens, including divine names (Eheie, Iod Tetragrammaton, Tetragrammaton Elohim, El Heseth, Elohim Gibor, Eloha, Sadai, Adonai Melech, etc.), Sephiroth, orders of the Blessed, archangels, heavenly spheres, sacred animals, human organs and parts of blood, tissues of man, and musical instruments. Various symbolic seals illustrating these correspondences are also included.

This brief chapter characterizes the Undenary as a number lacking merit, signifying 'sinners and penances.' It is described as exceeding the Denary (law and order) yet falling short of the Duodenary (grace and perfection), thus implying imperfection or negative connotations within the numerical symbolic system. Illustrations depict concepts related to the 'Soul of the World' without further specific enumerated correspondences.

The Duodenary (Father, Son, Holy Spirit) is presented as the pre-eminent means for the support of spirits and the number of the Celestial Signs. It systematically lists correspondences for each of the twelve zodiacal signs, including their angelic rulers, associated months, divinities, stones, animals, sacred birds, trees, and plants. This comprehensive framework links celestial influences to specific terrestrial and spiritual entities, facilitating operations aligned with zodiacal energies.

This extensive section provides critical commentary and scholarly notes on the Calendar's symbols and methods. It clarifies the origins of various elements, such as geomantic figures, Kabbalistic correlations, Agrippan magic squares, and spirits from the Arbatel of Magick. It offers detailed explanations for operative techniques like Onomancy (divination via name calculations), election of planetary hours for magical actions, and determining auspicious times for alchemical transmutations. The commentary also corrects perceived errors in the original engraving, contextualizes the material within the broader Hermetic tradition, and highlights the philosophical underpinnings of the Calendar's symbolic system.

key_concepts.definition: A large 1620 copperplate engraving, serving as a comprehensive visual and textual synthesis of Hermetic, Kabbalistic, and traditional magical symbolism from the Renaissance and medieval periods. It functions as a structured guide for understanding cosmic correspondences and operative magic.

The fundamental principle of Hermetic and sympathetic magic, establishing systematic links between divine names, angelic hierarchies, planets, zodiacal signs, terrestrial elements (metals, plants, animals), human anatomy, psychological states, and numbers. This framework enables a holistic understanding and manipulation of the universe.

A specific method of divination detailed within the Calendar, involving kabbalistic reduction of personal names (and parental names), planetary days, and the age of the Moon into numerical values. These values are then cross-referenced with various onomantic tables (e.g., Albumasar, Pythagoras, Ptolemy) to predict outcomes related to health, fortune, life, and death.

Twelve equal divisions of both day and night, each governed by a specific planet. Electing the correct planetary hour for a magical operation is deemed critical for aligning with favorable celestial influences and ensuring the success of the intended work, a central tenet of Renaissance magic.

Numerical grids (e.g., Saturn 3x3, Jupiter 4x4) associated with each planet. These squares are used as a basis for constructing the sigils of planetary Intelligences and Spirits through kabbalistic reduction of their names into numerical patterns, which are then traced on the grid.

Symbolic figures derived from magic squares and planetary associations, often representing planetary Intelligences and Spirits. They function as 'symbol-keys' designed to open awareness to specific planes of being and are intended for use in ritualistic or meditative magical work to channel or invoke particular cosmic forces.

The process of changing one metal into another, understood not merely as a physical act but as a spiritual operation. The Calendar provides guidelines for electing 'fit times' for transmutation, specifically by aligning operations with the Moon's degree in the Zodiac and the ruling planetary hour, reflecting the deep interconnectedness of celestial and material realms.

A holistic mode of cognition promoted by the Calendar, characterized by the ability to perceive profound interconnections and correspondences between seemingly diverse events, objects, and abstract ideas. This synthetic approach, often expressed through numerical and symbolic philosophies, is considered vital for spiritual development and understanding the nature of being.

The explicit intention behind the compilation of the Magical Calendar, which omits all 'demonic' or 'evil' associations typically found in some grimoire sources (like Agrippa). This emphasizes a purely spiritual, pure, and beneficial form of magical practice aimed at enlightenment and alignment with divine will.

practical_system.description: The Magical Calendar details a comprehensive system of sympathetic and numerical magic, providing a structured framework for understanding and operating within the cosmos. The system is built upon a vast network of correspondences, organized numerically from One to Twelve, linking divine names, angelic hierarchies, planets, zodiacal signs, elements, and human attributes. It emphasizes the active alignment of human will with celestial influences through precise timing and the use of potent symbolic tools.
tools: Detailed tables of planetary hours and their specific associations (e.g., materials, colors, body parts).
Planetary Magic Squares (Kamea) of varying dimensions (Saturn 3x3, Jupiter 4x4, Mars 5x5, Sun 6x6, Venus 7x7, Mercury 8x8, Moon 9x9) for deriving sigils and understanding numerical structures.
Sigils and Characters of planetary Intelligences and Spirits, designed as symbolic keys for ritual and meditative work.
Onomantic tables (e.g., Albumasar, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, Anthidonus, Plato, Aristotle, Hali) for performing numerological divination.
A universal dial for determining planetary rulership of hours and astronomical positions.
Knowledge of zodiacal signs and their daily associations for astrological timing.
Alchemical tables and principles for understanding the spiritual and material aspects of transformation.
The practice of 'Hermetic Thinking'—a holistic approach to perceive and work with cosmic interconnections and correspondences.
rituals: Electing specific planetary hours and days for magical operations to ensure alignment with favorable celestial influences and desired outcomes.
Utilizing planetary sigils and characters of Intelligences and Spirits in ritual or meditative practices to open awareness to specific planes of being, invoke forces, or effect changes.
Performing Onomancy for divination, involving kabbalistic calculations based on names and dates to predict fortune, health, or the outcome of various endeavors.
Determining auspicious timings for alchemical transmutations (e.g., changing metals) by aligning operations with the Moon's zodiacal degree and the ruling planetary hour.

relevant_quotes.text: The Calendar is a vehicle for a synthesis of magical and numerical symbolic philosophy, and there are no internal references which

The Magical Calendar is a bridge between what lived in early seventeenth-century Hermeticism and what can come into being as the future evolution of human consciousness. In this sense it is an important and still living work.
Choosing the correct hour for a magical operation was deemed of major importance in Renaissance magic, and tables with this information are found in many books and manuscripts.
The Quaternary, the root and foundation of the numbers, the fount of Nature, containing the perfect number.
The Senary is called the number of perfection, of the redemption, and of Man.
The Septenary, the vehicle of human life, the most complete number full of every power, sacred to the Holy Spirit.
The Octonary denotes the number of Eternity, of the preservation of health.
The Nonary of the celestial spheres and of the divine spirits, assisting in order, sacred to the Muses.
The Denary—The end and fulfillment of the Numbers—of many powers, a perfect number.

The Undenary has not any merit, just as it exceeds the Denary, which is of law and order, so it falls short of the Duodenary, which is grace and perfection: therefore this number is said to be that of sinners and penances.
The Duodenary, the number of the Celestial Signs, is the pre-eminent means for the support of spirits.

Sigils are symbol-keys that open us to awareness on that particular plane or realm of being. They should be used in ritual or meditative work, together with other symbols and structures relating to these levels.

The Kamea or Magical Squares of the planets can be used for constructing the pairs of sigils (those of the Intelligences and those of the Spirits of the seven planets), which are found in the outer ring of the Seal of each planet.

An Election of Time to be observed in the transmutation of Metals—if at any time you shall desire to Transmute and change any Metal into another kind, as Gold into Silver, or rather Silver into Gold, it is necessary that you learn to elect a fit time for that purpose out of the Table following, whereby you shall easier, sooner, and without danger bring your work to your desired end.
Magical or Hermetic thinking is the ability to see ideas as part of a whole—to see the interconnections, the correspondences, between seemingly diverse events, things and ideas.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Magical Calendar remains highly relevant as a foundational document for classical Hermetic and Renaissance magical philosophy. It serves as a comprehensive visual and textual compendium of correspondences and symbolic structures that deeply influenced subsequent grimoires and esoteric traditions. Its emphasis on holistic thinking, the practical application of correspondences for spiritual and material transformation, and its presentation as 'white magic' resonates with contemporary occult practitioners seeking to engage with traditional systems, offering a vital link to the evolution of human consciousness. The detailed commentary by McLean further enhances its accessibility and provides crucial scholarly context.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is primarily aimed at advanced students, academic researchers, and serious practitioners of Western Esotericism, Hermeticism, Kabbalah, and Renaissance magic. It is also suitable for those interested in the historical development of occult philosophy, ceremonial magic, astrological timing, onomancy, and alchemical symbolism. The detailed tables, sigils, and operational instructions make it particularly valuable for those seeking practical, operative knowledge within these traditional magical frameworks.
